reviewText:
If your horror movie tastes run less towards chainsaw-wielding maniacs and more towards things-that-go-bump-in-the-night, then this is the movie for you.  Based on a short story by the great Stephen King, "1408" is one of the genuine movie sleepers of summer 2007.

John Cusack gives a tour-de-force performance as Mike Enslin, a successful writer who specializes in the investigation of paranormal activity with a particular emphasis on hotel rooms that have the reputation for being haunted.  The twist is that Enslin is, essentially, a nonbeliever who spends most of his time and energy debunking the very subject off which he is making his living.  The 1408 of the title refers to a room in a swanky, five-star Manhattan hotel in which, we are told, no fewer than fifty-six guests checked in but never checked out, having met their untimely demises there in the decades since the establishment opened.  Determined to put an end to the "foolishness," Enslin moves into the room convinced he will ride out the night in utter peace and safety.  He has, of course, another think coming.

As adapted by Matt Greenberg, Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, "1408" succeeds mainly by keeping it straight and simple and by concentrating with laser-like focus on the character of Enslin and his relevant back story.  The multi-layered plotting keeps us guessing from first moment to last, so that we never quite know whether what Enslin is experiencing is really happening or whether he is suffering some form of mental breakdown brought on by the death of his young daughter and the subsequent breakup of his marriage a few years back.  Along with director Mikael Hafstrom, the master craftsmen responsible for the film's phenomenal art direction and sound recording draw us into the strange world they've created where nothing is quite what it appears to be and where we spend most of our time nervously scanning the edges of the frame to see what surprise is next poised to jump out at us.

Cusack, who has long been underrated as a performer, gets the chance to really show us his acting chops in this role.  He allows us to clearly see the fear and vulnerability hidden beneath his character's wisecracking, cynical exterior.  Samuel L. Jackson and Mary McCormack also excel in the small but pivotal roles of the wise hotel manager and Enslin's estranged but faithful wife, respectively.

For those who can remember a time when fright films had more on their minds than simple gore and grue, "1408" is like a refreshing, restorative tonic on a hot summer day.

First of all, I have to confess I'll see nearly  ANY movie with John Cusack in it. I'm not sure what it is about him as an actor that holds my attention but after seeing him in a wide range of films, I find his versatiliy, his ability to play a broad spectrum of characters and to keep  pushing the envelope and explore new territory to be intriguing. Don't get me wrong - I don't have a crush on him. He's an actor. I'm a reviewer - don't know the guy.

Now, ABOUT THIS MOVIE. I read the short story in King's collection and have to say that the movie takes lots of creative liberties but that's fine by me. It holds true to the essence of the story. I happen to like this in book form better but that is because it's taut and doesn't waste words. Besides, it is easier to linger on a certain passage, until it is seared into the imagination.

  Still, the movie has its fine points as well. As mentioned before, there is John Cusack, who definitely comes across as a skeptical writer who becomes genuinely spooked by his experiences in Room 1408. His acting is as interesting as usual, pulling out all the stops, with those quirky facial movements that can suggest so much about a character without saying a word.

I found the special effects to be less impressive and the movie seemed to go on forever. But that's my main problem with adaptations of King books to screen. Sometimes they work beautifully and other times they fall flat. I think this one is somewhere in the middle.

My wife and I went to see 1408 the other night. It was a birthday gift--otherwise she'd never have gone. She hates horror movies.

Interestingly, we both ended up enjoying the movie.

I read (or should I say listened to?) the short story prior to seeing the movie. Much like I prefer the movie version of the Shawshank Redemption, I prefer the movie version of 1408.

John Cusak is great. He usually is. Samuel Jackson gives a wonderful performance. Whoever the little girl actress is--she also did a remarkable job.

The ending rocks (I promise I won't spoil anything).

What makes this movie a little stronger than most horror fare is this:

1. The pacing is great. Things never go over the top by being too intense for too long. This has been a big issue in horror films lately. They lose their suspension of disbelief from too much emotional weight. I don't know about you, but I find myself mentally withdrawing from such stories to come up for air. When I re-engage, much is lost.

2. Speaking of suspension of disbelief wreckers...there is very little gore here. In this movie, when gore does come, it usually comes in the old photos. I feel this lack of abundant gore strengthens the pyschological impact of the movie as a whole. It also prevents the movie from turning plain old silly like recent gore-fests along the lines of The Hills Have Eyes.

While this is not my favorite Stephen King adaptation--Shawshank still reigns there--1408 is a solid, intelligent and emotionally resonant movie. You will not be wasting your money if you go to see this over the 4th of July holiday.

I give 1408 a strong recommendation.

PS- This also gets the award for best use of a Carpenters song in a horror film since In the Mouth of Madness.

When hearing the plot for this film, The Shining is most likely to come to mind. And even after seeing 1408, I still wonder how Stephen King could pull off this story with it being so similar to his other classic evil hotel tale. However, 1408 does have its own creepy style that will make the audience jump several times and is definitely worth seeing if you are a King fan or just enjoy a good scare.

Treading the familiar Stephen King territory of a writer thrown into the horrors of supernatural chaos, 1408 is more Shining than Misery, but Cusack retains the redeeming pathos-inducing personality of the latter's troubled novelist. Choosing to use atmosphere and mood over blood and guts to increase suspense, Mikael Hafstrom's thriller admirably shies away from cheap scares and ghostly Ring-like little girls to slowly build a searing psychological terror where the audience might lose their cool before Cusack's character does.

Mike Enslin's (John Cusack) tragic past provokes him to seek out the most notorious of haunted houses and other typical phantom hangouts and debunk the existence of such afterlife entities. After writing several less-than-successful "top 10" haunted locale books, Enslin happens upon a postcard warning to stay away from room 1408 in New York's Dolphin Hotel. Unable to resist, Enslin insists upon staying in the "evil" room that has claimed 56 lives and boasts a foreboding one-hour maximum life expectancy for its occupants. Ignoring the pleads of the Dolphin's manager (Samuel L. Jackson), Enslin embarks on a nightmarish night of supernatural torment where he must battle impending psychosis, paranormal devilry, and his own inner demons... and he may not last ten minutes let alone one hour.

Perhaps its greatest accomplishment, 1408's emphasis on atmosphere and setting over blood packets and gore effects keeps it refreshingly new though its premise dabbles in the horror stories of old. Those expecting the elaborately grotesque tortures of Saw and Hostel may be disappointed in the psychological terrors that reign supreme in this haunted hotel room, but just as effective (if not more so) is the steady building of unbearable torment on Mike Enslin's rapidly crumbling psyche. And through his faltering rationalizations, we too begin to lose our calm. Once the mysterious happenings transform into supernatural disturbances, the likes of which Enslin can no longer pass off as cunning trickery from the hotel manager, he must face his inner demons as well as the deceptive visions brought forth by the hellish room. When the inevitable jumpy scares finally do arrive, we're so worked up by the terrifying setting and nerve-wracking mental deterioration of our protagonist that we jump even higher out of our seats.

As Cusack's character changes from stubborn skeptic to mortified victim, his surroundings shift in appearance as well, almost like a less drastic Silent Hill, where the walls crack and bleed and an icy chill blankets the room in frost. The usage of such visual change in setting (especially later, when stormy waves flood the room) helps to keep Enslin a stranger in his surroundings, and therefore the audience as well, even though the film practically takes place all in one small location. The normally static environment becomes an unpredictable location where anything can happen.

1408 is virtually a one-man show, and Cusack embodies the perfect victim and empathetic host to the horrors unfolding. At first he is obstinately confident in the nonexistence of ghosts and such supernatural phenomena, but as the notorious one-hour time limit counts down (thanks to an unnerving alarm clock with a mind of its own), Enslin realizes just how wrong his assumptions were. An ingenious plot device has him dictate his thoughts into a tape recorder, allowing the audience to participate in his initially logical thought process that quickly deteriorates into a frantic rationalization of the eerie events he witnesses, and ultimately the realization that he will die in the cursed hotel room.

Though infused with plenty of cynical humor, the steadily increasing dread can't be shaken from Hafstrom's clever adaptation of Stephen King's short story. An inspired performance from Cusack keeps the suspense high and the hope of escape low, and the rising fear and paranoia parallel such horror greats as The Shining and Audition (as do the skillful psych-outs that toy with the audience and Enslin). And while our protagonist may be able to talk his way out of being frightened by the terrifying events unfolding (at least for a short while), chances are the audience won't be able to do the same.

- Joel Massie

"1408" is excellent! The cast led by John Cusack (in a great performance as Mike Enslin) and Samuel L. Jackson (as Gerald Olin) is great. The directing by Mikael Hafstrom (who also directed "Derailed" (2005) is great. The screenplay by Matt Greenberg (who also wrote the screenplay to "Halloween H20: 20 Years Later" (1998), Scott Alexander, & Larry Karaszewski (both who also wrote the upcoming "Cell" (2007), based on the novel also by King), based on the short story by Stephen King, is great. The music by Gabriel Yared (who also did the music to "Breaking And Entering" (2006) is excellent. The cinematography by Benoit Delhomme (who also did the cinematography to "Breaking And Entering") is excellent. The film editing by Peter Boyle (who also did the film editing to "Derailed" & "The Hours" (2002), which he was nominated for an Oscar) is great. The casting by Elaine Grainger & Lucinda Syson (who also did the casting to "Children Of Men" (2006) is great. The production design by Andrew Laws (who also did the production design to "Derailed" & "The Number 23" (2007) is excellent. The art direction by Stuart Kearns (who also did the art direction to "Batman Begins" (2005) & Doug J. Meerdink (who also did the art direction to "Ocean's Thirteen" (2007) is excellent. The set decoration by Daniel B. Clancy (who also did the set decoration to "Derailed" & "The Number 23") & Marina Morris is excellent. The costume design by Natalie Ward (who also did the costume design to "Derailed" & "Breaking And Entering" is great. This is an interesting suspense-horror-psychological thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat. This is one of the better horror films in recent history.

I have always been a huge Stephen King fan, and I'm happy to say that 1408 is not a bad adaptation by any means. The story does feel a little recycled from The Shining, but mainly because it deals with a hotel and the evil spirits that haunt it. The acting is pretty good, but some of the dialogue could have used some work.

Worth your dollar on a rainy day.

3 out of 5 stars

In a Haunted Hotel story, it always starts with a warning: Don't stay in that one room. It's haunted. It's evil. Such is the way that "1408" starts, an opening that inevitably leads to a series of nightmarish supernatural occurrences. But rather than bombarding the audience with cliched images of ghosts and monsters, the film effectively gets under the audience's skin by adding uncomfortable subtleties. Example: there's a moment when John Cusack passes a painting while in room 1408. He sees that it's slightly crooked. It wasn't like that when he first entered the room. Moments such as these build up as the film advances, resulting in a story that doesn't shock so much as it unnerves. In short, this is a film that takes us on one heck of a ride.

And no wonder; it's based on the short story by Stephen King. In the collection "Everything's Eventual," he introduces "1408" by saying, "hotel rooms are just naturally creepy places, don't you think? I mean, how many people have slept in that bed before you? How many of them were sick? How many were losing their minds?" I must admit that I don't put much thought into hotel rooms. Still, such unpleasant ideas ring true. The filmmakers must have known this; those very words were used as dialogue for Cusack's character Mike Enslin, a man who makes his living writing about reputedly haunted locations. Following the death of his daughter, he no longer believes in anything, least of all in ghosts. When he learns of New York City's Dolphin Hotel and the history behind room 1408 (whose digits add up to thirteen), he only sees it as an opportunity to add material to his next book. He intends to stay overnight.

The manager of the hotel--Gerald Olin (Samuel L. Jackson)--desperately tries to talk Enslin out of it, as such characters do in such stories. Room 1408 has been associated with many deaths during the Dolphin's ninety-plus year history: there was the sewing machine salesman that slit his own throat; there was the man that drowned in a bowl of soup; there was the woman that jumped from the room's window. Today, no one stays in room 1408. The only people who enter it are the maids, who give the room a very quick turn every month. The sheets are changed. The towels are replaced. The light bulbs are fixed. According to Olin, it's similar to holding your breath in a room filled with poison gas: everything has to be done quickly. This is because no one who stays in that room will last for more than an hour. Something is in that room. Not a ghost, but definitely something.

Enslin listens but refuses to reconsider. He sees Olin's words as nothing more than scare tactics, a way to drum up publicity for the hotel. Olin insists that he's being quite serious. Whatever the case, Enslin eventually receives the key to room 1408, an old-fashioned metal key that fits into an old-fashioned lock (the hotel has upgraded to magnetic cards, but according to Olin, nothing electronic will work in 1408). The room is located on the fourteenth floor ... but actually, it isn't. During the elevator ride, Enslin notices that the floor numbers go from twelve directly to fourteen; apparently, a thirteenth floor is highly frowned upon in many hotels. Either way, Enslin enters room 1408.

Thus begins a highly intense, horrific journey, highlighted by unexplainable occurrences, terrifying images, and otherworldly encounters. I won't bother describing them in detail: for one thing, it would be difficult to do so; for another thing, you really should experience this film for yourself. Let's be incredibly vague and say that many strange and frightening things happen, all of which force Enslin to reexamine his state of mind. For the horror movie aficionado, this film is delightfully unsettling, filled to the brim with pop out scares, spooky sounds, and startling twists of fate. At the same time, it utilizes smaller, quieter moments, such as when Enslin bathes the room in ultraviolet light, exposing large areas that were once covered with blood. In the hands of a lesser director, all this could have amounted to mere shock value, great to look at but lacking any substance.

Luckily, there's genuine imagination at work in "1408," so much so that it begins to get overwhelming. But that's how it should be; Enslin is learning the hard way, and the audience needs to be aware of this. Ultimately, I felt the same way leaving the theater as I did when finishing King's original story: thrilled. It doesn't matter that this film adaptation isn't completely faithful to its source; the story served more as a springboard than a strict guideline, allowing for many ideas to be expanded and solidified. When Cusack's strong performance is added to the mix, it gets even better; for most of the film, he had to act while alone in a hotel room, surrounded by a wealth of special effects. Nonetheless, he shows terrific range, relying on an emotional gamut that's just as convincing as it is intense.

"1408" is one of the better Stephen King adaptations of recent memory, a carefully crafted fright fest that knows how to make the audience uncomfortable. It's engaging, exciting, and genuinely terrifying, perfect for anyone in need of a good scare.

1408 is a well made ghost story with John Cusack as a writer who wants to write a story about a motel room that many people have died in. He actually stays in the room expecting it to be not that bad since he has stayed at haunted places in the past. Samuel L. Jackson is great as the motel manager eventhough he's short and white in the short story I think but while reading it, I pictured Samuel L. Jackson anyway. Samuel L. Jackson adds more humor and sarcasm to the part though. Anyway he's both creepy and funny in the small part as he practically begs Cusack not to stay in 1408 adding some hilarious Samuel L. Jackson style curse words. Soon after arriving in 1408 Cusack realizes that 1408 is the real deal and as much as he'd like to leave the room won't let him.

  The ghosts in 1408 can look like prejections from the Haunted House in Disney World, so they aren't that scary. But there's still pleanty of moments in the movie that will make you jump. The movie is also very entertaining but mostly due to the great work from John Cusack. He can make you laugh pleanty of times but the movie can also have it's emotional scenes which he handles fine as well. I admit there's a scene at the end where he had me close to tears. Despite some scares, the movie really wouldn't have been as good without him.

  Even if you read the story, there's no one else you can picture who's as perfect for the part. If you're not sure what Stephen King book you can find the story in, it's in Everything's Eventual by the way. I still have to finish it, I started reading this week before I saw the movie. I'll have to see if the ending is the same but here I really liked it a lot. The movie is worth checking out, that is if you're not expecting a whole lot of blood and guts and just want to see a movie with a good story.

first off: I did listen to the audio book version, if stephen king endorses it--then it must be pretty good and honest.  the movie does deliver in so many ways.  visually stunning, atmospheric and just creepy enough to keep you in your chair.  john and his wife had lost their child(insight for their current situation and his morose attitude) there really is no gore but it is suspenseful.  interspliced with shades of dark humor to cut the edge. john cusack is a writer who wants to witness paranormal experiences. he has traveled to many hotels with so-called hype or real events but is always disappointed.  he gets a postcard to go check out room 1408 in new york city at the dolphin hotel.  real stories of death and terror and when calling to get a reservation....its no, but after meeting with hotel operations chief-samuel jackson---the fun starts.  fast paced, real or not real, drugged or not-or just a BUMPY dream.  solid story, solid cast and unpredictable---hold on for its one hell of a ride. slick entertainment in the STEPHEN KING tradition---THUMBS UP!
Great movie
This is one of the best movies I've ever seen.  A child could watch it, and it's very suspenseful and scary!
Probably one of the most scary movies I've ever seen. I loved it!

It keeps you on the edge of your seat and might make you lose your finger nails from grabbing things out of nervousness. Its perfect from beginning to end in a stunning artsy way. I cant say enough good things about this film. Any time someone says they don't make good horror movies now days I show them this film! I give it a 10 outta 10!!

This is such a great movie! It will definitely pass the test of horror film though is so much better than a typical horror movie. There are only a few jump scares, one somewhat gory scene but most of the movie just messes with your head and embraces a psychological thriller. It probably won't keep you awake at night because it scared you so badly but it will absolutely give you chills. Without any spoilers, the ending is reasonably satisfying. YOU NEED TO SEE THIS MOVIE!

It's pretty much straight up John Cusack vs the room, and while the melodrama about his dead daughter can be a bit tedious, it makes up for it with a couple twists and some pretty good special effects.  Add in Samuel L Jackson and multiple endings and you've got a pretty good movie.  Makes it into my regular Halloween rotation.

I rarely (and I do mean rarely) watch "horror" movies. I feel like I've pretty much seen it all. I decided to give this one a try because I usually enjoy the talents of Jackson and Cusack. It seemed to me that Cusack had to carry this movie alone and struggled to do so. The evil hotel room is not a new concept and this one predictably missed the mark...same old, same old!

You want a scary movie? This room literally comes to life and takes you on a horror filled adventure. Starts slow, bur the pace picks up as the movie goes along. Ending leaves you wondering though. Movie is well conceived and executed. Enjoy.

This is a must-watch for horror-thriller fans. It may not be all the way up there with The Shining, but this is definitely one of the best Stephen King film adaptations I've ever seen. I'd never watched a John Cusack movie before this, and his acting is absolutely pitch-perfect (which it needs to be, since he's alone onscreen for most of the movie).

This is one of those horror films that goes for a creepy atmosphere and psychological thrills over gore and/or jump scares. In other words, it's one of those truly scary movies that also happens to be artfully written and produced. I actually liked the film more than the original short story.

I do prefer the theatrical ending over the director's cut, which is what you're getting here, but both radically different endings have their pros and cons.

The only thing that made this movie good was John Cusack.  I didn't think this movie was going to be like this and I am not a fan of ghost movies at all.  There was hardly a plot and a dark, disappointing ending.  And to have children take part in a movie like this is just not right.  Like I said if it wasn't for Mr. Cusack I would have given it one star but I could look at him all day.

John Cusak has done so many movies, he's no longer John Cusak the actor but John Cusak playing the same character in every movie. He's a solid actor but fails to really stretch himself. Combine that with subpar movies and I came into this one with low expectations. Low enough that this is a movie I've been wanting to see but refused to until it came to Amazon Prime. As a member I wholeheartedly dug into it. I wasn't disappointed. It keeps you on the edge of your seats and you find yourself more interested in the characters that make up the room, i.e. the previous residents. The color of the movie was outstanding as it wasn't dark and the acting overall was solid as well. I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone. As far as an actual rental, I see a $1.99 fee about as much as one should pay.

Nobody can help Mike,  he is on his own to find his path and what he wants.  Light suspense, bit of terror and lot of paranormal events.  Nice for a home weekend!

Unfortunately, this was just an "okay" movie. The scare factor was mild and the character seemed to go through psychological processing of his past rather than dealing with the events in the room. The history of deaths in the room seemed to drive Samuel Jackson's character into not wanting to allow John Cusack's character to be in the room, and though those deaths were mildly hit upon, they were *only* mildly hit upon. It was that history as to WHY those people killed themselves and why the room was so-called "evil" that drove me to want to watch the movie. The movie turned out to be a narrative of only what was going on with the Cusack character, instead. Some ghosts made their appearances, and one quick-shot scare at the end, and due to those reasons, I really would not recommend this movie.

1408 while being an interesting film that held my interest had its own set of downfalls. While taking a refreshing look at horrors by coming from the perspective of a skeptic haunted hotel  writer it still held some common tropes and cliches of the modern horror industry. At times during the film, I was unsure of whether I was watching a horror movie or a mind twisting version of Inception. I believe one of the largest downfalls of the film was playing so far into the haunting of the room that it no longer seemed like it was the actual room that was paranormal. Beyond the hallucinogens and somewhat trippy experiences of the room, after the main protagonist seemingly vanquished the room there is a tease that some of the haunting still remains in his personal belongings, which destroys the entire aspect of the room being the subject of the haunting.
However all in all I was kept on the edge of my seat and startled my fair share. I would give it a 7/10 and would probably watch again.

"1408" is almost good, but it just misses the mark. The film runs too long to sustain the atmosphere they are trying to build, and while the cast is good, I think the film would've been better with Cusack playing the hotel manager and Sam Jackson as the writer.

Mike Enslin travels the country staying at, and writing about, the haunted hotels of America. Mike is a skeptic when it comes to the supernatural, and would love to have a genuine ghostly encounter, but so far, he's just sensationalized his stories and packaged them together in book form. It seems that Mike was at one time, an up and coming author, but due to a family tragedy, he's left serious writing behind.

Mike gets a postcard from The Dolphin Hotel suggesting he come and stay in room 1408. Mike thinks this is just another hotel looking to catch some free publicity in one of his books, but soon finds there is more to 1408 than the usual ghost stories.

I liked King's short story that this film is based on, and I appreciate who the film makers fleshed out the story. And I also appreciate that "1408" isn't found footage (seems like this would be a ripe tale to tell using camcorders and iPhones), and it's not a jump-scare-a-thon like the "Paranormal Activity" movies. They actually try for suspense and chills instead of just giving loud noises as things appear on screen.

With that said, "1408" is actually a pretty dull film. Way too much time is spent on Mike's backstory, and as the events of Mike's life unfold, we may be saddened or sympathetic to Mike.....but we aren't scared.

I admired the performances of both Cusack and Jackson, as well as the overall premise of the film. My only real nitpick is the overly dramatic orchestra music from time to time, in scenes where it doesn't really fit. Otherwise, 1408 is a quick and decently spooky film for a fun evening.

Modern horror has gone through many different phases and while "1408" is not as flashy, loud, or as gory as many modern films; Stephen King's story and the adapted film still is an effective look at what is one part psychological thriller and one part haunted house. While the premise of "1408" is simple, the success of the film is carried largely on the dissection of its main character and the dialog (at times literally) established with the room itself. Much like the worlds of "Silent Hill" or "As Above, So Below", "1408" is populated by the shades and ghosts of its current occupant. And while much of the past still is present in every action the room takes to breakdown it's victim; the viewer is left to try and establish just what exactly is going on and where the line between reality and delusion ultimately is. For many this film may seem dated and not as edgy as modern horror films, strong scenes i.e. (Jackson warning Cusack to stay out of room 1408) still do a nice job of building up actual tension even before the main event has even started. Although "1408" does show its age and some of the scares are hit and miss, it still offers an interesting look into the journey of overcoming one's personal demons and is worth a look.
Ok

Disappointed after protagonist enters 1408. It was a good set-up until then. Movie was made or released in 2007, and we've all had plenty of time to learn all of the horror/thriller memes. Let play parapsychologist for a moment, ok? As soon as the window slams on his hand, and the vanity sink water becomes scalding steam, and the radio turns on spontaneously with "It's only just begun..." he has to know there is something different about 1408. He is such a stickler for being rational, so...why doesnt he write down, journal all the events up to the point of the door lock not turning, and the key breaking, and then take methodical drastic measures. We all know from movies like Christine that when radios turns themselves on, there is a haunting in progress. Ditto for doors that were functional moments ago, refusing to open. Basic horror trope stuff. At that point, Mike needs to jot everything down on paper, and on his laptop, and on his audio recorder: the window slam, the scalding tap, the spontaneous radio, and the door lock failure, key breakage. At that point, he loses it and it becomes special effects and dreamland/memoryland/fantasyland stuff. All he needed to do, was disassemble the bed, and remove one steel rail, and use it to batter the thinner door panels until they break, and crawl out of the recalcitrant doorway, and he's out of the room. He failed to stay calm after each weird manifestation, take stock of what is happening, and think slowly and carefully. Because of that, he missed using a simple lever or a battering ram to exit the door. Riskier, would have been igniting a towel drenched in alcohol on the end of his battering ram, and setting the door ablaze and then kicking it when it was weak. Multiple pragmatic solutions to get out of the room with a phantom-locked doorknob, and he opts to go crazy, drink more, and just react instead of act. Very disappointing once he enters 1408. I wrote this review as catharsis. I get it...the room was "supposed" to get him, ergo, he's not allowed to think up ways to get out of the room that make sense.

As far as bad horror movies go 1408 is surprisingly decent. I can't say too much without spoiling it, but the attempts at horror here actually work okay for a one-man show. The movie is never particularly scary and the main character isn't very likable or relatable, but the writing manages to convey a psychological threat. Apparently this is based on a short story, and it shows in the quality of the writing.

If you get a chance to rent it (or watch for free through Prime) and you're into horror films you might as well try it.

John Cusack plays a skeptic, who writes books about the most haunted vacation spots there are.  He doesn't believe in anything.  No ghosts, no ghouls, and no gods.  He receives a postcard about room 1408, and decides to check it out, even though he "knows" he will find nothing.

Samuel L Jackson plays the hotel manager, who does whatever he can to try and convince Cusack not to stay in that room in the hotel.  He believes the room is evil, and perhaps even alive.

Cusack stays, and the horror begins.  There aren't any monsters popping out at you, though there are a few startling occurrences.  You won't see Freddy or Jason, or anyone horrifically covered in scars.  It's more of a subtle horror.  Cusack does well in his role, making you believe he is seeing what we see.  The torture is supposedly never ending, with only one way out.

Over all, 1408 is an excellent example of what a horror movie can be, without all the cheap thrills.  It has an entertaining story, and some interesting characters.  It's worth a watch.

This movie is a good scare for me, since I only watch horror movies every blue moon.  Staying in that room is like going to Hell on Acid or a potent strand of Cannabis.  I'm only guessing with the Acid, but I can vouche on behalf MJ.  Not only is this movie creepy, but the story is nicely done.  I mean it's almost as if it was copied straight from a book, which in turn was written by a talented and successful author- whose books I can never bring myself to read.  That's the thing about King's work; it always pushes my buttons on what I feel is taboo and superstitious.  This movie really activated my fight-or-flight response without really overwhelming me.  Yeah, it's PG-13; maybe I'm a sissy, but I enjoyed this film.

I liked the deviation of the story from the original story and it did a great job of portraying the lead as a prisoner.

I was a bit disappointed in the ending, however, as it was !not! the ending that I watched when the film came out in theatres, nor was it the same as the book.  I found that disappointing in that it appeared that the producers of the film attempted to make it some how more unsettling, but I found the original ending much more clever.

I've seen this twice and even enjoyed it the second time.  It's an often overlooked gem of a thriller (horror?) movie with two good lead actors.  I was attracted to the idea of a total skeptic of the paranormal/ghosts taking the challenge to stay in a room with a reputation for killing it's tenants.  The movie does a good job of pacing the tension such that it steadily grows to a final climax and the main character is given a chance to develop as this happens. I'm a Stephen King fan, and this movie is based on his story.  It really isn't a horror movie so much as its a psychological thriller that makes you question how you would react if you were in such an impossible situation?

PS: It doesn't get 5 stars mostly because  John Cusack, is a decent actor, but not five star in this.

This movie is about one thing: COGNITIVE DISSONANCE." That is the inability to accept the truth even though it may be backed up with evidence, documentation and, most importantly, HISTORICAL precedents. The hotel manager (Jackson) tried to tell Enslin (Cusack) not to take room 1408. He gave him hard evidence of what happened to people who stayed in that room. A whole lot of it. He finally gave one last heart-felt plea for him not to stay in the room. So what does Enslin do? He did what any pretentious, jaded, egoistic, pompous, know-it-all hack would do. So guess what? He was warned. Just like any know-it-all who watches mainstream media and believes everything they're told by the sock puppet news casters (spell-casters is more appropriate) and wonders why things NEVER GET ANY BETTER AND ONLY GET WORSE. If you tell a child not to put their finger on a hot burner, some very inquisitive children may try to test that "theory" before they believe it. Good for them. They now have empirical evidence and will not do it again. But try telling a physically sick adult something about the poison junk they call "food" they eat every day and wonder why they get sick and stay sick. Try telling them about the lies perpetrated by the mainstream regarding current false-flag events (See screen shot from this movie. Remind you of anything?). They call you a "conspiracy theorist" at best. Oh well, they were warned. The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results. Happy voting. Every movie made in holly wood (sic) is rampant with occult symbology and correspondences. Take the number, 1408 (and does anyone really have to write it down to add up four numbers like he did in the movie?). So they add up to 13. Oh, "unlucky 13." Well, it's also the card, Death (XIV), in the Tarot deck. Maybe that's how it became so unlucky. "2254 Lexington Ave" (the address of the Dolphin Hotel) also adds up to 13. Guess they really want to push the Death card. But what does 1 + 3 equal? Four; the Emperor in the Tarot (IV). Why is this important? Because emperors (rulers like presidents) are responsible for a lot of innocent people being killed, even though they get their order-following minions/lackeys to do the actual killing in MOST cases (hey, learn from House of Cards). They are psychopaths. It's no coincidence that Enslin mentions "the banality of evil," from a book by political theorist Hannah Arendt called Eichmann in Jerusalem: A Report on the Banality of Evil originally published in 1963. It's not really funny that Eichmann said he was "just doing my job" about planning and executing the murders etc of millions. But what about the zero in 1408? Card 0 is The Fool. The Fool means a lot more than what the name implies but the surface meaning is obvious. Anyway, it's funny that the Emperor card should come up. "Enslin" happens to be an anagram for Lin Sen; Chairman of China in 1932. He was called by Time magazine "puppet President Lin" in 1934. I don't know for a fact that that's what the writers of this movie intended, but it is a very strange coincidence. Hmm, know of any puppet presidents from the US? I do. Every one of them from the day JFK was murdered by the CIA and military. I could go on and on about other things I noticed in this movie but what's the point? No one is listening. Hey, enjoy your stay. Don't say you weren't warned. And congratulations to all the five star and one line reviewers. You are legends.

I have to give this 5 stars! We have watched the 6 or 7 times since the movie came out... Who but Mr. King could make a hotel room scary.... TWICE!... You could easily be tricked into thinking this is a repeat of The Shining... but 1408 has a story of it's own... And it managed to stay scary but not gory! All too often horror movies get it wrong now a days... they think the trick to scaring is to make it vomit worthy. I don't  equate the two. Just because I can't watch your movie while eating a plate of Spaghetti does not mean your movie was AT ALL scary... I prefer the mind bending scary. The scary that makes you think... The scary that makes you question if you have possibly met a serial killer... or ... how much do you actually know about your neighbors... LOL... This has enough scary with a limited cast and scene's... So EPIC in that department as well...You have to give them credit for doing this film without much of a travel budget. I don't want to write a review that tells you ABOUT the movie... I want to write a review that makes you wonder what's in that movie that I haven't seen!? Todays horror movies are missing what this one has! Watch it! The way horror should be done!

A pretty ridiculous premise for a movie.  The plot is about a writer who specializes in debunking haunted building rumors.  He doesn't believe in the supernatural.  He gets a postcard from someone about this hotel in New York that has a very haunted room in it.  He sets out to debunk the rumor for his next book.  The hotel manager vigorously tries to discourage him from staying in the room, citing all the previous deaths but this is viewed by the writer as "salesmanship."  The writer checks in and the room goes to work on him.  The room seems capable of altering reality and perceptions of it but no explanation is given as to what power is behind it.  Its tactics are dastardly and it seems to somehow have intimate knowledge about the writer's deepest fears and issues.  The enemy throughout the movie is clearly "the room" itself and there is never any suggestion of what power is behind the room's haunting, which makes this plot quite unbelievable.  Most supernatural thrillers invoke a spiritual world which contains intelligent entities who are bent on doing humans harm, but a constructed room simply can't do this with any stretch of the imagination.

Not the best Stephen King movie-from-fiction I've ever seen. The plot is simple. A hack writer who likes to write books about haunted places gets a recommend about a particular hotel room -- 1408 in The Dolphin. The head concierge of the hotel tries to talk him out of staying the night, but this writer has heard everything before. He's a complete nonbeliever and very angry. He refuses to listen, and stays in the room.

The rest is just an escalating series of supernatural events, climax and denouement. I won't detail it all because too many spoilers. I didn't think the events were all that imaginative. Stephen King can do and has done -- much better work. I thought the events in the haunted room were poorly strung together and rather plotless. I don't like being creeped out just for the sake of being creeped out. There needs to be a reason, a story -- something -- that can connect me to the haunts and weirdness. This was disconnected. I laughed through a lot of it because it was so over-the-top for no particular reason that I could discover. I liked the hack writer goes to haunted hotel beginning --that was a good place to start. But then it deteriorated.

Awesome, good movie based on Steven King short story.

Guy ends up in a hotel room which is, within its walls, endowed with total omniscience and omnipotence. The evil room toys with him to try to get him to kill himself even though the room could kill him itself. Then, inexplicably, in the end he manages to "kill" the room with a molotov cocktail with alcohol and matches overlooked by the room. Nonsensical plot line ruins any chance of redeeming itself or its star actors. That being said, it does potentially beg the viewer to look existentially at the human condition and the prisons we create in our minds. If you miss that nugget, you might hate this film.

The most disturbing dark "scary" movie I ever watched. Horrific, cruel & claustrophobic in a low key way. John Cusack is the only one on the screen most of the move & he really pulls it off. I've watched it a dozen times since 2007 & it still gives me shivers. The movie has come out with 2 different endings which drastically change the movie. I prefer the original ending I saw at the theatre when it was released in 2007. This edition on Amazon is NOT best ending. The original ending leaves you with a glimmer of hope for Mike Enslin. This ending is sad & gloomy. But it's still Stephen King at his creepiest.

This is another ghost story, not totally dissimilar from The Shining, but also of the genre of "bet you can't stay in the haunted house over night" dares. John Cusak does a pretty good job. Samuel Jackson works at the hotel, never really sure who he is or what he does. The story starts out as expected with things moving around, and goes way off into dreamy nightmare land by the end. It's dark and moody, as a horror movie should be, but I can't say I understand any of it in the end. So, if you don't care about story line to much, okay. Otherwise, you're constantly left trying to guess whether he's having psychological problems or he's having a really bad day with some kind of ghosty thingy.

Let me preface this by saying 1408 is one of my favorite horror films of all time--but I do NOT like this version of the film.  This version presents an alternative ending that is not NEARLY as satisfying as the original.  DON"T watch this version--go rent or buy the original--this is the alternate ending. The theatrical ending to this movie is 100% better than the lame "alternate" ending here. The one I saw in theaters gave me true goosebumps and was one of the few endings I actually enjoyed in any horror movie. While I still strongly recommend watching, it sucks because the ending you see will not do the movie justice. You will have to search for the actual ending online if you want to see it, which obviously spoils the flow of watching it streaming. Overall, the movie itself is well done, creepy, and I got a few good jump-scares out of it. A firm 4/5 stars for me with the better ending, otherwise 3/5 stars.

I had seen this many years ago, and remember it being good. I learned in re-watching that i was not mistaken, then. Everything about this slow-burn horror flick is very well done, but the main attraction is John Cusack's excellent performance as paranormal myth-buster who is, quite literally, taken down by an "evil f*&king room". It's Mike Enslin v. Room 1408 and, given that it is an excellent Stephen King penned tale, you already know who is going to win. That's the trick, the treat is watching it happen - watching the supremely confident Enslin literally unravel before your eyes, and watching the excellent special effects-supported process of the room, quite literally destroying him mindy, body and spirit. Great, great stuff.

This is one fun movie! It's scary as heck, but kind of in an old-school fashion. One of the best things about this film is absence - nothing happens, but the psychological tension builds anyway. It's a sorta sophisticated horror film, and I think it goes beyond genre film-making (a stupid categorical label anyway) because beyond the horror aspect there is the matter of a father who has repressed the mourning of his daughter's death, and you don't know if room 1408 is real or if it's a man learning to liberate himself from his own personal demons. Fun, scary, and intelligent. I was aching to see a film like this, and it hit the spot!

I really enjoy 'ghost stories'. Haunted house stories are ones that really draw me in. So when I saw this movie by Stephen King I thought this is one I'd probably really enjoy. Unfortunately it was not the case at all. It had such great potential. A story about a man named Michael who wants to spend the night in the dreaded room 1408 at the Dolphin Hotel could have been loaded with real scary stuff. Instead, it was a complete let down. I am not one for gore or sex in movies so in that aspect it was fine. But I AM wanting to be scared. This story had mostly to do with Michael spending the night in a room (by the way, 1408 adds up to 13 in a hotel floor that doesn't have a 13th floor labeled) that gives him flashbacks of his young daughter's death. Oh, you see a few black and white transparent ghosts that just look at him and leap out the window. And there seems to be some kind of phantom who you see a few seconds at a time who swings an axe at Michael. There is also some kind of ghost who chases him for a short time in a furnace duct but that's about it. If Michael is haunted by his own family's past, fine. But I don't care about that as a viewer. It doesn't make me cry or go crazy. I wanted to see ghosts unexpectedly come out from somewhere to give me a fright. I wanted something to shake ME up. Unfortunately it wasn't there at all. One thing about me is that I am a bit backwards from other people. I would rather watch the movie first and then read the story because if I read the story first it kind of ruins the movie for me. After I saw this movie I read the short story (In Stephen Kings' book 'Everything's Eventual'). The short story was better and had some scarier images. I also saw how the movie had to add lots of unnecessary filler that could have been used better to keep him in the room longer with scarier images. Sorry, but this just was not even remotely scary. I know there are reviewers out there who found it to be scary. That is fine. Horror is different for everyone. It does take more to scare me in movies. Many people thought the movie "The Conjuring" and even its sequel "Annabelle" very scary. To me, they were both just dramas with little scares at all. Stephen King has some good stories even though I don't think they are scary at all. 'Christine', 'Pet Sematary', 'The Shining', 'Misery', 'The Mist', 'Cujo', 'Storm of the Century', 'Salem's Lot' all come to mind. I like those stories very much. But none of them scare me in any way, shape or form. Even if this wasn't scary it still could have been a good story to read or watch as the ones previously mentioned. But this one fell flat on all accounts for me. It reminds me of 'A Good Marriage'. That had a great premise as well. A woman who finds out years after she is married that her husband is a serial killer. Wow, what a great idea! Unfortunately that too was a complete waste of time for me. Sorry, but I doubt I'll be re-watching this one.

This movie is a reversal of H. G. Wells' far-superior short story "The Red Room." In Wells' story, the suspected ghost is not a ghost, and the action takes place in the room of a supposedly haunted castle; in this film, the suspected ghost is a ghost, and the action takes place in a supposedly haunted hotel room. The differences in quality are many, but the primary one is that Wells could write, whereas neither King (who wrote the short story "1408") nor the screenwriters (who wrote the screenplay of the film) can. Well's masterful short story works; King's story and the film based on it both fail, quite embarrassingly.

This has a touch of "The Matrix" and "Inception". Just touches, not on the same level by any means. It almost seems more like a made-for-TV movie. But, it's not bad. Be careful, you might have dreams about it. And it might impact the next time you sleep in a hotel room.

Jackson but this is one film he didn't need to be in because his character was pointless. 1408 is "supposed" to be about an evil room and in my opinion failed to show me exactly what was so evil about it. After watching this movie, it just seemed that Cusack's characters guilt got the best of him. In conclusion this was a good try at a psychological thriller but not quite good enough.

This film was is shot in the atmosphere of a Thriller and mystery. I was pleased with what I have seen! I especially want to thank the Director Mikael Hfstrm for his ability to convey in this film the spirit of Stephen King. Here there are no ridiculous and cheap tricks, which are usually intended to invoke fear in the viewer. On the contrary, the film begins carefree. We are introduced to with writer named Mike Enslin, who skillfully played by John Cusack. His character became famous for books about the paranormal. But Mr Enslin skeptical about the possible existence of ghosts. Oh, how wrong he was! The fate brought him to the hotel room 1408, which was infamous. He was warned about the dangers associated with staying in this room. But as a true skeptic, Mr. Enslin didn't believe and decided to spend the night in this room. From that moment, we, the viewers, will together with the hero, to go through a lot of intense and mystical scenes. The reality will be embodied in the illusion of perception, and Enslin will be trapped. Can he get out? Or not?

As for me, I freak out whenever I hear a song start playing unexpectedly anymore.

So scared that I had to watch this movie twice. The first time around I had my eyes closed through a bunch of it!

So, I did the dumb thing and read the short story just before watching the movie, so take that into account when reading this review.
The movie itself was watchable, if a little disjointed and somewhat hard to follow, but saying that it's based on Kings story is more of a cruel joke than an accurate description.
Two characters in the book made it into the movie, but since they were the only two chacters in the book (the writer and the hotel manager), it would have been impossible to leave them out.  Apart from that, I counted 3 vague references to the book.  3.
The film makers added several chacters, presumably for us to hate.  The ex-wife made me want to punch her in the face within 2 minutes of being on screen.  When your ex calls you, obviously freaking out and tells you to call the police and save his life, you don't start whining about how he didn't call you when he got into town.  She was begging to be hated, which seems to be the only reason she was in the movie - because trying to build a background for the writer failed miserably.
Then starts this whole thing where the room tries to convince him he seeing his dead daughter, and he starts to lose it.  again, adding characters to the story that weren't needed.
I'm just disgusted with this movie.  The book made the room a truely malevolent entity.  The movie made it a kinda creepy and surreal place to be, it was so watered down if I didn't know it was based on the book I never would have recognised it.  The stupid film didn't even get the pictures on the wall right!!!!
Things that really pissed me off because it wasn't supposed to happen: He left the room (at least he thought he did), he interacted with other people while in the room, he was able to contact people outside the room, he crawled around the freakinig vents and found a dusty corpse that of course (in crappy, predictable movie fashion) came to life and chased him through the ducts, the list could go on for as long as the movie, which seemed endless.
Honestly, it was such a struggle to watch the last half hour, I didn't think I would get through it, but I had to see how much more the film makers could screw up the story - and on that point they take the cake, all of the cake, even the crumbs.
Then the writer dies at the end, which wasn't supposed to happen, and the story was much more disturbing knowing that for the rest of his life he had to sleep with the lights on so when he woke from his nightmares he instantly knew he was not in that room any more.
John Cusack delivers an amazing performance, and is really the reason to watch this movie, the only reason.  He is believable, genuine, and with all the other things I hated about this film, I still found him compelling.
Sam Jackson was good as well, but his character was poorly written and in no way resembled a hotel manager.

Conclusion:  Skip the movie and read the story.  (Don't worry, America, it's a short story)
very enjoyable, and I've re-watched it twice. It's a good haunted house movie that is instead set in a hotel.

Ok, Let me start by saying that I love almost all things Stephen King.  This film is absolutely no exception. It is atmospheric, creepy and deliciously dark.  That being said- let me just say this. First, there will be NO SPOILERS here. Yes there is more than one ending to the film, and people differ wildly in their reactions, but I'll say that each alternative ending leads you intrgued and wondering and wishing the film could continue on for more.

Cusack is at his best here, because with the exception of a  'bookend' setup-scene and concluding appearance by a truly creepy and ambiguous Samuel Jackson, this is a one-man film. Cusack is onscreen, alone, for the entire film. And he's brilliant here.
The closest acting achievement (carrying an entire film singe handed) I can recall is Tom Hanks in 'CAST AWAY'.

Cusack is a jaded, cynical writer whose niche is investigating (and debunking) supposed 'haunted hotels'. When he checks into Room 1408, everything seems mundane, just another rundown hotel on hard times whose Manager hopes to bring in traffic with some 'haunted room' publicity. But then...
Is the room truly possessed by an evil intelligence? Is Cusack hallucinating? Has the hotel Manager somehow drugged him? Is he losing his mind? The film supports any interpretation you choose.
Special effects are remarkable, especially considering this is a one-room set, with virtually the entire film taking place within the walls of Room 1408.
But the real brilliance here is an intelligent plot, a psychologically complex and multi-layered script, a truly gifted actor in Cusack, and more (I promised no spoilers).
'1408' is infinitely re-watchable, and each time you'll catch a nuance, a clue, a misdirection you missed the first time. Be sure to watch it with someone, you'll want to discuss it for hours afterwards.
5 stars. This is one to own. Probably the most truly frightening film of the last 10 years.

I don't normally like (or watch) nightmarish video.  This is yet another poltergeist horror film, but with psychological suspense rooted in the protagonist's own personal grief.  So it feels real even while it isn't.  A ghost or spirit, in classical literature may be more accurately imagined as a shade or shadow of the person which once was.  While I don't thrive on spooky stories, this one fixed my attention on the screen, palms sweating in supense.  The protagonist is a self professed atheist who's lost his daughter (and his marriage) to a childhood disease.

As a Christian, I'll hazard to venture upon extra  Biblical traditions, and notice that some American native cultures include traditions of the spirit of the deceased remaining for a prescribed time among family and friends.  But untimely death may cause a spirit to linger aimlessly.  To the Christian perspective, the parent and child in this story are lost (wanderers), but not aimlessly.  In some ways, the purity of her ghost is what causes this story to transcend the boundary lines of pointless living or pointless death.

Christian scripture omits any instance of a God who pounces upon human souls, demanding, "what did you do with my son?"  What one does in life is, rather, the foundation or essence of what one's life becomes, in present and future time events.  Our mortal frame doesn't fully calculate the power of love, on the horror in this tale, where love, a team venture, intrudes more terribly than  the sickness of death.

For those who don't know, this movie was based off a short story of the same name written by Stephen King back in 1999. The story itself is about a skeptical writer Mike Enslin (played by John Cusack), who travels the country trying to debunk ghost stories by visiting haunted houses and anything purported to be haunted. In the movie he is bitter and atheistic after the untimely death of his young daughter from some type of cancer. Then one day as he is sorting through his mail he comes across an anonymous postcard featuring the fictional 'Dolphin Hotel' built in 1912 (1910 in the book) and on the back of the postcard it's written "Don't enter 1408". Mike Enslin takes this as a challenge and tries to get access to room 1408 but finds that the hotel manager has forbidden anyone from entering the room because of all the people who have died in that room (56 in all). Mike uses an old civil rights law to bypass the hotel's rules and manages to get inside room 1408. It isn't long before things start to get very surreal and very insane. And the worst part is the room won't let Mike escape.

The room isn't haunted, rather the room itself is encompassed by some malevolent supernatural entity that manages to get inside the minds of the people who go into the room and ultimately causes them to commit suicide. Whether this entity is a demon or something else entirely is never made clear. What also doesn't make sense is the origin of the entity which is never explained. For example, how is a single room that's not even on ground level just happened to randomly be possessed upon its completion. It's just that specific room in the hotel that's the problem, not the hotel itself. And since the room is 13 stories up (not on ground level), it's not as if there was anything that happened in that particular space where it was built. That particular space was air before the room was built. These are questions which I have and will never get answered but which add to the mystique of the story itself. How does a room become evil? It's as if the room just somehow became a portal into another dimension, a dimension we would probably think of as Hell since in the movie it seems as if Mike Enslin is experiencing a kind of Dante's Inferno plotline as he finds himself deeper down into a colder and darker and even more inescapable situation. The room becomes more and more of a prison and more and more surreal.

This movie. THIS MOVIE IS ALL OF MY YES. I loved it so much. It's almost stupid how much I love this movie. But please, for the love of all things good...watch the ORIGINAL, DVD VERSION. The thing with the Blu-Ray is....if you want to own it, fine, but at least also have a copy of this on DVD you watch first because the dumbest thing they did was change the ending when they put it on blu-ray. This is how I mean that. They didn't simply add an "alternate ending" to the extras in the blu-ray menu...NO. They quite literally CHANGED THE ENDING when it went to blu-ray. WHAT THE ACTUAL EFF??! They took the alternate ending, and then when it went to blu-ray, decided to make it the actual ending for the blu-ray. Who does that? The original ending makes it. Are you kidding?? And the endings are VERY different. DAMMIT BLU RAY DECIDER PEOPLE, CAN YOU HEAR ME??! STOP. YOU'RE WRECKING THIS MOVIE AND I HATE YOU WITH THE FIERY PASSION OF A THOUSAND BURNING SUNS and not the cool kind of sun that wears sunglasses and appears on children's stickers or artwork either, no, a f*$#ing ANGRY sun, with fire. Honestly. This movie was so incredibly well made, and so intense, gripping, and creepy without being gory or cheap or ridiculous...and I'm hard to please with movies! So I hope every one who likes good movies, will watch this. BUT NOT THE STUPID BLU RAY ending way. But the original, way-it-was-supposed-to-be way. THEN you can go ahead and watch all the alternate endings you want (I think there were 2, or 3) but watch it with the original ending first. Or you might hate the whole movie when the ending is crap. Again, if you want to own the blu-ray, cool. We prefer blu-ray to dvd now too, but keep the DVD version around.

1408 is a difficult film to judge. John Cusack stars as a man who specializes in debunking paranormal occurrences in Room 1408 at the Dolphin Hotel. It is fairly loyal to the original Stephen King short story and has two great actors, Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson, but it doesn't quite work overall as a horror flick because some of the visuals hurt the movie (e.g. when we see the ghosts and other paranormal activity). There isn't much in the way of gore, violence or shocks so it works more as a psychological thriller. By all rights it starts out by building a decent amount of tension but it doesn't really pay off. It just does not come across because we don't feel emotionally involved in the film despite some good performances. Jackson isn't really in the movie enough to share billing with Cusack. Some scenes are downright dull despite having a fairly good premise and set-up. It is probably 15 minutes too long for its source material. The Blu-ray picture quality is average but the sound is fairly good. The original theatrical cut of the film is missing on Blu-ray (only the unrated version is provided) but the theatrical ending is available as a bonus. There is 44 minutes of total bonus content.

The secret to good horror is not gore and gratuitous violence; good horror is about a tight, gripping, tense story that finds its protagonist not confronted by wave after wave of meat cleaver violence, but confronted by the sheer terror that has been planted in his mind.  Accordingly, 1408 was quite the treat; I caught this film on cable and instantly was attracted to the story of a writer who doesn't believe in the supernatural, and writes stories basically debunking paranormal occurrences, getting scared out of his gourd while staying in the infamous Room 1408 of the (fictional) Dolphin Hotel in New York.  And Room 1408 throws the proverbial kitchen sink at the writer, almost from the moment he checks in--from faucets exploding super hot water to blood oozing from the walls.  And during the haunting the writer (played masterfully by John Cusack) is forced to confront, and relive, the most painful experience in his life.

Cusack is completely believable as paranormal author Mike Enslin.  The actor brings the right mix of skepticism, incredulity, and self-deprecating humor to this role.  Mike Enslin is becoming a believer in the supernatural right before our eyes, and is it ever fun to watch.  Samuel Jackson is his usual antagonistic best playing the manager of the Dolphin Hotel who tries, without success, to convince Enslin not to go to Room 1408.  It's a surprisingly small role, but Jackson brings his usual in-your-face vigor.  The story is suspenseful and compelling, again sans the meat grinder gore, with one star off due to the complete predictability of the faux resolution Enslin encounters.  The real ending sends goose bumps down one's spine, making 1408 a most satisfying horror yarn.  See this movie and it will change your perception of The Carpenters forever.
--D. Mikels, Esq.

As I usually do, I found John Cusak to  have done the best he could with the material he had to work with. Jackson had little  more than a walk-on in one scene, not anywhere near enough to warrant co-star  billing. He did well with the little he had to do. My problem with the film was that all the artificiality was showing, that is, it was like watching the rehearsals for a play, seeing all the backstage business, and reading the script while seeing the production falling into place.  I never was led to believe that this was a movie of a NYC hotel in which  a lot of stage business was going on.. Perhaps a better analogy is that of a magicians assistant who knows the mechanics behind every trick.
In sum, I can't say for sure, but there is a good chance that a fan of this kind of  movie is not going to be able to take it very seriously. I didn't but, then, I am not a fan of the genre.
Postscript:  Just watched it again after some years interval in which I have completely forgotten ever having seen it. Perhaps I have grown less critical as a very old man, but I did find it much more appealing than I clearly did at the first viewing. It is still a distance from first class and certainly overwrought ..........but now I would recommend it to everyone who goes for the spookier, less naturalist film.

1408 follows Mike Enslin, a horror author and supernatural investigator, as he visit the Dolphin Hotel to stay in the infamous room 1408 - a room home to over 50 deaths, including grizzly suicide and odd natural deaths. 1408 is a fantastic and frightening supernatural/psychological thriller.

The story in this film is straightforward. It uses supernatural (was that a ghost?) and psychological (is it all in my head?) elements to create an effective horror atmosphere. There's suspense, creepiness, and many jump scares spread throughout the film, along with a few great twists in the plot. The setting is also fantastic, as mentioned in the film, hotel rooms are naturally creepy; room 1408, however, is a special case as it changes constantly - the weather conditions, particularly, change often. Basically, the film works great as a psychological and a supernatural horror film. The music is also magnificent. The acting was also great. The pace is moderate during the first 30 minutes, then it goes into a very fast pace.

Overall, 1408 is an exceptional horror film that masterfully executes its supernatural/psychological blend, packing a creepy and constantly changing setting and a lot of scares. A purchase is highly recommended for fans of horror, a rental otherwise.

Saw this in movie they're and loved it , got the DVD just wasn't the same , I got a blu ray player and I had to get this movie it's so much like in theatre , my favorite by far of scary movies , keeps you on edge of seat  and the ending is great
I had a lot of expectations for this movie, they were not met at all.  Another waste of time for me.

Probably the most accurate translation of one of Stephen Kings books to film since Misery.  More of a ghost or haunting story than horror but rest assured it's wonderfully terrifying.

A long time fan of John Cusack (and his sister Joan) Mr. Cusack turns in an incredibly layered and focused performance as  Mike Enslin  an unhappy more or less washed up and washed out author of haunted places.

His past which we see in both flash back and unsettling recreations explains the reasons for his the disgruntled attitude which masks his pain - the performance is superb.

Samuel L Jackson as the hotel manager Gerald Olin, does what he does best and that's deliver a commanding performance. Tony Shalhoub provides a bit of comic relief but laughs are few and scares are plenty.

The Dolphin hotel is as much a character in the film as Cusack - I have to be careful here in not giving anything away but it's like The Shinning in that the Overlook Hotel had a life of it's own as does room 1408. The feeling of dread when Cusack enters the room is palatable.

There is no gore here, splatter fans won't be happy. This is a thinking horror fans movie armed with genuine scares from a rich woven plot.

Director Mikal Hafstrom (The Rite) leads us into an ominous world of twists and unexpected, truly frightening moments, the effects are outstanding and the film is peppered with images that will haunt you long after the final credits have rolled.

A must for any Stephen King fan - I know hotel rooms may never seem the same to me and that's the stuff of great movie making.
this is a very good movie in my opinion. It keeps you on the edge of your seat. Some people may not care for it but i did.
Wanted to see this one for a long time but forgot about it. Not one to give anything away on movies. It does have some good suspense.

1408 is one of those movies you're either going to really love or really hate. It's long, and at times, not easy to sit through, but if you're a fan of Stephen King, you should be used to that. This is vintage King and it's done right! When people don't like the movie, right away they go after the writer. They don't realize that a lot of times things are drastically changed to make them more visually appealing. In a horror flick, that's usually means tits and/or gore, which are out of place in a King story. 1408 has none of that, it's just a good old fashion horror story about a room that possesses it's residence. The acting isn't going to blow you away, there aren't very many surprises as far as the story goes, but it's a scary story, done the way the master of horror intended and I liked it!
I liked that movie a lot. I watched on HD after connecting my laptop to HDMI cable to the TV and really enjoyed it.
A great paranormal thriller, lots of twists and turns. Cusack does his best to not believe but in the end........
I like the movie.  This is what I call a movie when it is is not what you expect.  The storyline is not traditional but new in concept.  Also, I like the actors John Cusack and Samuel Jackson/

Stephen King's novels and stories rarely translate well to screen, for whatever reason, This one is no exception. John Cusack does okay as the jaded writer, aka Stephen King, who doesn't believe in ghosts. So, he checks into a NYC hotel room where 56 people have died horrible deaths. He proceeds to hang out the window for 20 minutes, while ghosts jump out over him. Then, the room begins to go crazy, as you would expect. There isn't a single jolt in the entire film. And we get some predictable nonsense about the lead character's dead daughter coming back to haunt him. I don't know what the budget was, but this feels like a little film. Watch it for some mild entertainment.
Very good movie - I'm a Stephen King fan and this story translated well to the screen- well directed and acted by John Cusack. Give it a try.

Even the scariest movies lose effectiveness over subsequent viewings, but there's a lot to like about this one nonetheless. Drags a little toward the end, but great visuals and interesting narrative arc. Cusack is great.

An evil hotel room? Who would've thought that would make for such an awesome movie? It was an amazing story, but movie? Yeah, worth the 3 bux for rental even tough I messed around and didn't get to see the end. (yes, I've seen this before. No biggie)
